proof:
Based on Proposition 10 and Lemma 35, a positive real constant $A$ exists such that for any sufficiently large $d$, it holds with high probability that all connected sets $S$ of size at least $A\log(n)/d$ have a total degree of $\mathrm{degg}(S) > \frac{9d}{10}|S|$. If, in addition, the set size satisfies $|S| \le \frac{n}{6}$, then the number of internal edges is bounded by $e_G(S) \le (1+\frac{1}{5})|S|$.

The total degree of a set $S$ is given by the identity $\mathrm{degg}(S) = 2e_G(S) + |E_G(S,S)|$, where $|E_G(S,S)|$ is the number of edges with one endpoint in $S$ and the other in its complement. By rearranging this equation and applying the inequalities mentioned above, we can conclude that for any connected vertex set $S$ with $A\log(n)/d \le |S| \le \frac{n}{6}$:
$$
\frac{|E_G(S,S)|}{\mathrm{degg}(S)} = 1 - \frac{2e_G(S)}{\mathrm{degg}(S)} \ge 1 - \frac{20}{9d} - \frac{1}{5}.
$$
For a sufficiently large $d$, this quantity is at most $\frac{3}{5}$.

To complete the proof, we observe that if a set has size $|S| \ge \frac{n}{6}$, its total degree is at least $\frac{3dn}{10}$. With high probability, this value is greater than the total number of edges in the graph, $|E_G|$, and therefore also greater than the number of edges in the component $C$, which means $\frac{\mathrm{degg}(V_c)}{10} < \frac{3nd}{10} < \mathrm{degg}(S)$. Consequently, any set $S$ that satisfies $\mathrm{degg}(S) \le \mathrm{degg}(V_c)/10$ must also have a size of $|S| \le n/6$. This implies that the expansion property is applicable.
